content:
My friend had a clash where they initially did well on all the tests, but unfortunately, ended up scoring 0% because they failed all the validators. It would be helpful if the test cases and validators were aligned with each other.

Here was his ruby code for reference:
puts`dd`.upcase.split.map{|w|w.chars.sum{_1.match?(/[A-Z]/)?_1.ord: 0}.to_s+w.gsub(/[A-Z]/,'')}*' '
You should add a visible test that tests the "nothing if no letters" case. Currently they're all in validators.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a good clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Hi, good clash, thx.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good for CoC!
Thanks! Now, the game has a better aspect.

Hi, cool contribution! A few points that could be improved before approval:

* Please use another symbol than ">" to mark a list, e.g. "-" or "*", since ">" is usually used in e-mails to make a quote block.
* Please place all constants or data in {{ and }} so they can be identified visually, e.g. "This sentence =>> {{Hello, ...}} will be ==> {{372, ...}}". Thus, you won't need double quotes in the next line, only {{ and }}.
* Please name the variable [[cleartext]] in the input, e.g. "<<First line:>> The [[cleartext]] to transform.".
* Please add the prefix "<<First line:>>" in the output (optional).
* For languages having to deal with buffers, such as C, please indicate the maximum size of the input in the constraints, e.g. "0 < length([[cleartext]]) < 100".

Thanks :)
Tank you for these tips. I have taken them into account to improve the game.

Goal
* Please change "all characters" to "all letters".

* Please rewrite the second point as:
> for every word, replace it with the sum of the ASCII codes of its letters; keep all other characters unchanged.

* An example has been shown in Example section. Please EITHER delete the example in Goal section, OR add some explanation to it.

Output
* Please rewrite as:
Encrypted version of the input text

Thanks.
Thank you. In the future please use the "Reply" button so that others will be notified of your replies.
Yes, if a word is only numeric, that is no letters, we take the numeric as it comes.

Yes, but the problem is there is currently no visible test case for that. Players who fail to take it into account get 100% from tests but when they submit they will be surprised to only get 20% from the validators.
